@VetAnalyst @RCVSpresident @RCVS_CEO @_VetSurgeon @vettimesuk I'm sorry but this is a total mischaracterisation of what it actually says. These warnings would apply to findings of *serious professional misconduct*, and it is *an alternative* to holding a full Disciplinary hearing. Most serious cases will still go to DC.

After going through Committee reports (available here: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T) the public session of the November meeting of #RCVSCouncil wraps up - the next meeting will be on Thursday 20 January 2022.

#RCVSCouncil approves a new ethical investment policy for RCVS assets which includes divesting assets from fossil fuels, following a recommendation from the Environment & Sustainability Working Party.
#RCVSCouncil vote to accept grads from EAEVE-accredited schools at the point at which the graduate completed their programme.

The next item on the #RCVSCouncil agenda is around accepting grads from EAEVE-accredited schools & whether we should use status of the school at the point at which the graduate completed their programme, or from the most current list of accredited schools supplied by EAEVE

After a long debate #RCVSCouncil majority votes to approve the new accreditation standards & methodology with the caveat that further work is carried out on defining general practice education as well as the implementation/ transition period for new standards

.@DrSuePatdermvet says that vet schools will be given sufficient time to adapt to the changes to accreditation standards & methodology with implementation taking place from January 2023 onwards: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T

The next item for decision is new accreditation standards & methodology for UK vet degrees introduced by @DrSuePatdermvet - she highlights improvements around diversity, sustainability, general practice education and its outcomes-based focus. Full papers: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T

#RCVSCouncil has voted to approve practicalities for implementing the new Stage 1 Preliminary Investigation Committees and Charter Case Protocol/ Committee - with the exception of the name for the latter which will be further discussed by Council members: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T

#RCVSCouncil are asked to approve practicalities of the new Stage 1 PICs & Charter Case Protocol - an alternative means of resolving cases that reach the threshold for Disciplinary, but are on lower end of the seriousness scale. Reforms had been approved at previous meeting.

After a magnum opus of updates from @RCVS_CEO we now move on to items for decision - starting with an item on the discretionary fund and approval of the Legislation Working Party's interim recommendations for reform of the concerns investigation/ disciplinary system #RCVSCouncil

Regarding overseas vets @RCVS_CEO updates #RCVSCouncil on the expanded package of support available for refugee vets as well as the launch of a survey with EU-qualified vets on the impact of the UK leaving the EU.

With #COP26 still underway @RCVS_CEO says the announcement of the new sustainability requirements for the PSS was particularly timely - the College is also working towards Investors in the Environment accreditation #RCVSCouncil
.@RCVS_CEO updates #RCVSCouncil on the #LegislationWorkingParty recommendations and says the RCVS has been talking to MPs, Peers and other key stakeholders about the proposals over the past months

.@RCVS_CEO gives #RCVSCouncil an update on current work & projects including the upcoming @ViVetUK   Workforce Summit & EMS stakeholder meeting, the VN Day One Competences consultation and #VetGDP: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T
.@RCVSpresident Kate Richards now opens proceedings for this month's #RCVSCouncil meeting - full agenda and papers are available here: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T

The November 21 meeting of #RCVSCouncil starts at 10am and items on the agenda include our new accreditation standards & methodology for vet degrees, interim reforms to our disciplinary procedures & recognition policy for EAEVE accredited schools: https://t.co/GgRDFZL59T

.@johnfinnes now closes proceedings for this evening, thanking those who helped put the evening together, his fellow presenter @RCVSpresident & those watching, as well as congratulating the new Fellows. Thank you all for joining us at #RCVSfellowship

.@RCVSpresident thanks @timspector for a fascinating talk, saying it demonstrates that while standardised approaches are useful templates, we also have to try and consider the particular circumstances of what‚Äôs in front of us #RCVSfellowship
Congratulations @AmyNRichardson1
Congratulations again Samuel! #RCVSfellowship https://t.co/6tniPQhzct
If you want to watch Tim‚Äôs talk in full please remember you can livestream this evening‚Äôs event at: https://t.co/w6AqC4oWIQ

Tim‚Äôs talk 'The Future of Personalised Nutrition' looks at how personalised nutrition, a concept that recommends food that best suits our own unique needs and circumstances, is breaking the dogma of a ‚Äòone-size-fits-all‚Äô approach to food #RCVSfellowship

One specific area the twins study looks at is nutrition and it has demonstrated that everyone, including identical twins, react differently to the same foods & identified sleep, exercise, meal-timing and sugar dips as additional personalised factors surrounding nutrition

For the final part of #RCVSfellowship @RCVSpresident introduces @timspector Professor of Genetic Epidemiology at Kings College London, scientific co-founder of ZOE ltd and, for the last 25 years, has been studying 12,000 twins in the world‚Äôs largest study of adult twins https://t.co/sqTjnJz7mU

Before playing Amy Richardson‚Äôs presentation in full @johnfinnes thanks the other four finalists: James Cockroft from Nottingham Vet School, Georgina Hopkins from the RVC, Stephen John from Surrey Vet School & Sophie Rosenzweig from Liverpool Vet School #RCVSfellowship

The winning presentation ‚Äì as decided by the judging panel ‚Äì was Amy Richardson, for her talk entitled ‚ÄòImplications of Mycobacterial Disease Surveillance on the Health and Welfare of Freshwater Aquarium Fish at ZSL London Zoo #RCVSfellowship https://t.co/DKmtVuUaZP

For the highly commended presentation the judging panel chose Samuel Pearce from the University of Bristol with his talk entitled ‚ÄòA Cross-sectional Study on Enteric Disease Agents in UK deer‚Äô. Congrats Samuel! #RCVSfellowship https://t.co/XUHxmBpgox

We now move on to the Fellows of the Future competition and @johnfinnes praises the amount of engagement from veterinary students with 23 applications to take part which was shortlisted to six finalists, each of whom recorded their talks #RCVSfellowship
Remember ‚Äì you can watch all three of the Fellows in Focus presentations at: https://t.co/oNm7rWBPYq #RCVSfellowship

Christopher Shales‚Äô talk is entitled The integration of webinars within our practice and explores how he and the team at Willows have used video-conferencing technology to maintain their contact with their colleagues, other practices and pet owners over the past 18 months https://t.co/NKu807EnYq

Joan Smyth‚Äôs talk is entitled ‚ÄòSome discoveries of novel diseases and concepts through diagnostic veterinary pathology‚Äô and explores how novel diseases can sometimes be discovered during the course of anatomic pathology or examinations of animals for routine purposes https://t.co/ypMe1Y1u2p

Mandy Peffers‚Äô talk is called ‚ÄòFrom bovine embryo transfer vet to Wellcome Trust Clinical Intermediate Fellow‚Äô and explores her unusual career path into academia and highlights some important factors to consider when pursuing a veterinary research career in academia https://t.co/CurMcxDmTY

Before announcing the winners of the Fellows of the Future competition @johnfinnes thanks the three Fellows ‚Äì Mandy Peffers, Christopher Shales and Joan Smyth ‚Äì who spoke about their research for the Fellows in Focus presentations #RCVSfellowship

@RCVSpresident adds that the Fellowship Week has highlighted the breadth and depth of the knowledge within the Fellowship and that the Fellows of the Future competition has both inspired her and reassured her of the future of the profession #RCVSfellowship

She adds that as RCVS Fellows, they are in a privileged position to help amplify the veterinary voice, build connections and collaborations with each other, with other health professions, and with the public, for the benefit of society #RCVSfellowship

Following the admissions @RCVSpresident now gives a short speech, saying that the new Fellows have demonstrated how veterinary professionals add value to both the profession and wider society #RCVSfellowship

Lastly are the 20 new Fellows through Meritorious Contribution to Clinical Practice, the route for those who can demonstrate outstanding professional achievements, including clinical or educational scholarship or leadership, and creation and interpretation of new knowledge

Next to be welcomed are eight Fellows through Meritorious Contribution to Knowledge, the route for those who have made an outstanding contribution to the advancement of knowledge in their field, including, for example, scientific or educational scholarship and leadership

First welcomed are 10 Fellows through Meritorious Contribution to the Profession, the route for those who have made an outstanding contribution and positive impact on the advancement of the profession, showing demonstrable leadership in their chosen area of expertise

John is now joined by @RCVSpresident Kate Richards to formally welcome the 38 new Fellows into the learned society at #RCVSfellowship and congratulate them on their achievement https://t.co/uygWTSzg43

The continued development of the Fellowship Directory ‚Äì a resource for Fellows to communicate with each other, the profession and the public on their areas of expertise ‚Äì is also highlighted. The Directory can be accessed here: https://t.co/8iUYRxJZxe

@johnfinnes says he‚Äôs particularly pleased that, this year for the first time, more than half of those being welcomed to the Fellowship are women and that this is a great move forward, although more needs to be done on diversity

He says that the Fellowship, led by Vice-Chair Cheryl Scudamore, has been working to improve diversity with unconscious bias & recruitment training and looking at diversity amongst panellists as well.

The World Health Organisation recently deemed propofol an ‚Äòessential medicine‚Äô and at the time of that decision, more than 190 million people had received the drug ‚Äì all thanks to Dr Glen‚Äôs vision, creativity and persistence in its development. Congratulations! #RCVSawards 3/3

It was at ICI Pharmaceuticals that he led a team that examined the efficacy and safety of using propofol as an intravenous anaesthetic agent ‚Äì receiving UK approval in 1986 - and is now licensed in over 90 countries #RCVSawards 2/3

Please make sure to follow Kate who has now taken over the presidential Twitter account. You can also continue to follow Mandisa on her personal Twitter account @mandisagreene1 https://t.co/0rPvEZsl2b
Just to note - all the key addresses from today's #RCVSAGM will be published on our website in due course and a summary of the occasion will be published in the news section
She concludes by saying that her overall aim is to amplify and extend the reach of the veterinary voice and with that the 2021 #RCVSAGM is brought to a close - thank you for joining us!

Kate says the priority for her presidential year is to encourage Connections which Count, making sure we look after ourselves so that connections can be built across veterinary and allied professions for the good of animal and human health and welfare, society and environment

She says that through initiatives such as The Links Project which highlights the connections between animal and domestic abuse, vets have a vital connection with human health and welfare by reporting animals they suspect of non-accidental injury #RCVSAGM

Kate says this is why she is passionate about projects such as @vetmindmatters and @VetlifeVBF that help those who feel disconnected and looks forward to building domestic & international connections to collaborate, extend knowledge and forge support networks #RCVSAGM
She says that the Covid pandemic has demonstrated the value of connections for our mental health and wellbeing. Social distancing has spotlighted the need for social connections #RCVSAGM

Having experienced loneliness and anxiety early in her career Kate says she's learned that connections count, the value and benefit of connections on personal, professional and societal levels and that it‚Äôs the simple things that add most value to life #RCVSAGM

In Kate's inaugural address as RCVS President she says she is the sum and product of her connections and stands here as a result of the support of many people - including her family, her colleagues and her professional mentors #RCVSAGM

Next Kate welcomes Niall Connell as RCVS Treasurer and Melissa Donald as Junior VP ‚Äì she notes that Melissa is a particularly keen runner and says she is glad she successfully ran for office - praising her chairing of Standards Committee particularly during Covid-era #RCVSAGM https://t.co/90xEhKCpmB
She then hands over the Past-President‚Äôs badge to Mandisa in acknowledgement of her achievements ‚Äì thank you Mandisa! #RCVSAGM

Kate‚Äôs first task is paying tribute to her predecessor with the historic nature of Mandisa‚Äôs presidency as first black woman in the role, her guidance of #RCVSCouncil through challenging times & difficult decisions and her integrity, fairness and attention to detail #RCVAGM
Congratulations to Kate Richards who is now formally invested as RCVS President for 2021-22 with the Presidential Chain of Office #RCVSAGM https://t.co/q5WpHz0Vjx

Mandisa also says that Kate's career highlights the diversity of opportunities that being a vet can bring as it  has encompassed being a practising farm vet, working in the pharmaceutical industry and working as a senior civil servant #RCVSAGM

Moving on to formal investiture of new President Kate Richards, Mandisa highlights her service on #RCVSCouncil including as Standards Committee chair where she presided over establishment of Ethics Review Panel & beginning of under care review process #RCVSAGM

She also praises outgoing Senior VP Niall Connell (who is now Treasurer) for his always kind and humourous presence at meetings and events, his work on diversity & inclusion, and his calm leadership during early days of the pandemic #RCVSAGM https://t.co/OmIpN221Sg

Before moving on to the investiture of Kate Richards as RCVS President, Mandisa praises the outgoing Treasurer Sue Dawson for her work in the Officer Team and Covid Taskforce on the financial impact of the pandemic and the sale of Belgravia House #RCVSAGM

Wrapping up Mandisa says that this year has made her recognise that she‚Äôs part of a profession that can weather all storms and an RCVS team that will continue to deliver for the professions and public, come what may #RCVSAGM

The highlight of her year has been the many talks she‚Äôs conducted with school students up and down the UK, many of whom are interested in veterinary work and says that lack of diversity isn‚Äôt inevitable & that we therefore need to deal with the barriers that exist #RCVSAGM

She says she‚Äôs realised that, though her presidential year had ended, the work in areas such as recognising the immense contribution of general practitioners and diversity & inclusion is never done and she & others will continue to work on these issues #RCVSAGM

Mandisa says she‚Äôs been inspired by her vet & VN colleagues who‚Äôve put their personal worries over the pandemic aside to continue to do their vital work for animal health/welfare and gives her condolences to those who‚Äôve lost loved ones #RCVSAGM

Matt now hands over to Mandisa as outgoing President, she opens with an anecdote about a plaque her parents gave her bearing the words ‚ÄòThings turn out best for those who make the best of the way things turn out‚Äô which has been her guiding ethos this year #RCVSAGM https://t.co/Nw8WVhEAV8

Matt wraps up by saying the VN profession has a promising future ahead of it with protection of title, enhancement of the VN role in anaesthesia, & separation of delegation from employment embedded in any future legislation #RCVSAGM

There will also be lots of Diamond Jubilee activities including a webinar series on the past, present & future of profession, podcast interviews with prominent VNs and an eBook on the VN profession‚Äôs journey #RCVSAGM

Matt says 2021 is not only about the past but also present as it will be a year of many firsts for VNs ‚Äì including the first CertAVN awarded, the first VN PSS Assessors, introduction of Advanced Veterinary Nursing status & hopefully 20K RVNs for the first time #RCVSAGM

Next is VN Council Chair Matthew Rendle who talks about what an important year 2021 is for the veterinary nursing profession with its Diamond Jubilee ‚Äì 60 years since the first RCVS-accredited nursing training course #RCVSAGM https://t.co/nxnRgi7QT3

.@RCVS_CEO wraps up by praising #RCVSCouncil members, the Officer Team and the RCVS staff for the extra work they‚Äôve carried out this year and handling the crisis with determination, grace, flexibility and compassion #RCVSAGM

Despite Covid @RCVS_CEO says there‚Äôve still been very significant achievements including VetGDP launch, the Legislative Reform Consultation, the under care/ OOH review, the Diversity & Inclusion Strategy & international collaboration with @vetmindmatters

She opens saying that the response to Covid often dominated the year with over 30 different temporary policy changes, and regular updates to our guidance and that, as we approach a return to normality, we will still be gauging its impact #RCVSAGM

#RCVSCouncil is currently going through the reports from the Committees - the full reports from each can be found in the papers: https://t.co/aRKhExWcej

#RCVSCouncil votes against the 'interim recommendation' to change the standard of proof, noting that the change of standard should wait for the recently approved introduction of a full fitness to practise model, of which the civil standard will be an integral part.

#RCVSCouncil also votes to approve Charter Case Protocol where cases that meet the threshold for a full disciplinary hearing, but which might be likely to attract a low sanction, may be concluded without a public hearing. More details in this article: https://t.co/6C6peZGzcI
In terms of the interim proposals #RCVSCouncil votes to approve the establishment of 'mini-PICs' allowing for a speedier and more streamlined concerns investigation process

#RCVSCouncil votes by majority to accept all of the legislative recommendations (the interim recommendations inc. standard of proof are being considered separately) meaning they are now RCVS policy and will form the basis for discussions with @DefraGovUK on new legislation.

Members of #RCVSCouncil are being asked to decide whether to adopt some or all of the Legislative Reform Consultation's recommendations, as well as implementing some or all of the interim recommendations on changes to the College's disciplinary processes.
The final report and recommendations - which take into account responses to the consultation - can be found in the papers to #RCVSCouncil: https://t.co/RLTzNYYTqG

Council votes to improve the broad series of recommendations on the future of meetings which will be fine-tuned in the future.

Thank you everyone who joined us for #VNevening from the RCVS Team and congratulations once again to our new RVNs and Advanced Veterinary Nursing Diplomates!

Thank you to Anne-Marie for an excellent presentation! Matthew now moves on to the three things he wants from the newly-qualified RVNs - never say you're 'just a veterinary nurse'; it's OK to not be OK; and remember you are a leader and a mentor #VNevening

Anne-Marie gives examples of techniques to improve resilience and find calm including micro-awareness/ mindfulness and meditation and how we can build these techniques into a habit for everyday life #VNevening

Anne-Marie says that resilience is about how we react to adversity - it's not an innate ability but about developing the skills we use to bounce back and recover from the unexpected events that life throws at us #VNevening

Anne-Marie talks about how tough the past year and a half has been for both the new and established veterinary nurses and praises them for their persistence and discipline in continuing to learn and work throughout such a challenging time #VNevening
We now move on to our guest speaker, leadership coach/ consultant and vet surgeon Anne-Marie Aylott with her talk Turning resilience theory into resilient vet nurses #VNevening

Matthew Rendle now talks about Diamond Jubilee which, while celebrating the past, will also be a year of firsts for the profession including the award of first CertAVNs, reaching 20k VNs on the Register, VNs becoming PSS Assessors & the introduction of Advanced VN status

Julie highlights some of the successes of #VNFutures including the development of the new Certificate in Advanced Veterinary Nursing, the School Ambassadors programme, and publishing career case studies & blogs. More available here: https://t.co/p7R62kEbgX #VNEvening

We now move on to RCVS Director of Veterinary Nursing Julie Dugmore who is talking about #VNFutures, a joint RCVS and @bvnauk project that aims to ensure that veterinary nursing is a vibrant, rewarding and sustainable profession ‚Äì now and into the future #VNevening https://t.co/tXNhoO9Rh9
She reflects on her own experience of working alongside many brilliant veterinary nurses and learning from them and says that VNs are a force for good for animal health and welfare #VNevening

.@RCVSpresident now gives her formal address - in which she asks members of the profession to continue to be curious, make sure to know your own value, and be honest about & learn from your mistakes https://t.co/a0bCagDakx

We now move on to those being awarded their DipAVN this #VNevening an advanced qualification for VNs allowing them to further their professional skills & knowledge across a variety of areas  such as anaesthesia, intensive care, and diagnostic imaging. Congrats all!

In their closing remarks @rcvspresident and Matthew remind guests to check out the #VNFutures project, respond to the legislative reform consultation (https://t.co/d1xNJ5ZDNn), and thank all those attending and the RCVS Coms Team for organising the event #VNevening üëèüëèüëèüëè

Following Hayley‚Äôs talk @rcvspresident thanks her for giving an inspiring presentation about all the different opportunities that are opened up for you by a veterinary nursing qualification #VNevening

Currently in practise in Derbyshire, Hayley‚Äôs work has taken her to nine countries across four continents, including in China where she nursed bears rescued from the bear bile farming trade #VNevening

In introducing Hayley, @rcvspresident says she received the honour in 2014 for her international, teaching and clinical work at the University of Edinburgh Hospital for Small Animals, and the Jeanne Marchig International Centre for Animal Welfare Education @JMICAWE #VNevening

We now move on to our last guest speaker for #VNevening Hayley Walters MBE who received the Golden Jubilee Award in 2014 and will be giving a talk entitled ‚ÄòFrom Bosnia to Vietnam: where a veterinary nursing career can take you‚Äô https://t.co/qJ4vp8VzYT

Thank you to Julie for her talk & overview of the key aims of #VNFutures ‚Äì remember you can find out how to get involved and read more information and resources on the project‚Äôs dedicated website: https://t.co/6diwurUDZC #VNevening

We now move on to a presentation from RCVS Director of Vet Nursing Julie Dugmore who is talking about the current status of the joint RCVS and @bvnauk #VNFutures project and the aims of its next stage ‚Äì more info on project here: https://t.co/6diwurUDZC https://t.co/onhRAj3wTW
Following Jane‚Äôs speech @rcvspresident comments that she is a great reminder of how vets and VNs work best when they work together & how the different skillsets complement each other #VNevening

Before her talk begins @rcvspresident notes that Jane received the Golden Jubilee Award for making veterinary nursing a recognised branch of equine veterinary practice, cementing the value of VNs as part of the vet team and for her mentoring of many veterinary students #VNevening

We now move on to the guest speakers segment of #VNevening starting with 2019 Golden Jubilee Award winner Jane Devaney with her talk entitled ‚ÄòFrom graduation to Golden Jubilee: how a veterinary nursing career can lead to great things‚Äô https://t.co/DKzudmfKlb
Lastly, @RCVSpresident says that this should be a proud moment for them all, as well as for their families and friends, for their teachers and mentors, and for the profession as a whole #VNevening

Mandisa says that as a vet she‚Äôs incredibly proud to have worked alongside fantastic VNs during her career, from whom she has learned so much from and says they will all be great ambassadors for their profession @rcvspresident #VNevening

Before moving on to the guest speakers, Mandisa @rcvspresident will now give a formal address for #VNevening in which she reiterates that the context of the new VNs achieving their qualification during the pandemic is particularly admirable

Mandisa @rcvspresident and Matthew now move on to congratulate the VNs who‚Äôve achieved their Diploma in Advanced Veterinary Nursing for their hard work in achieving the qualification which allows them to further their professional skills and knowledge #VNevening
Following the declaration there is now a roll-call of all those who have recently joined the Register #VNevening

Matthew now takes the newly-qualified nurses through the declaration which includes a solemn promise to pursue work with integrity & be responsible to the public, clients, the profession and the RCVS and do their utmost to ensure health & welfare of animals in their care https://t.co/IPP6nCjYgC

After Matthew‚Äôs address we now move on to the professional declarations & formal entry to the Register which @rcvspresident says makes those new VNs fully accountable professionals adhering to the Code of Professional Conduct #VNevening

Matthew now asks some things of the new VNs: never refer to yourself as ‚Äòjust a nurse‚Äô; always introduce yourself to clients as a vet nurse; always wear your VN badge with pride; and don‚Äôt forget to enjoy it! #VNevening

Matthew now gives his top tips for new VNs: don‚Äôt expect to be amazing from the start; where you are is not who you are; take breaks when you can; don‚Äôt be a know it all; every career is different & it‚Äôs OK not to be OK #VNevening

Matthew Rendle now gives his opening address for #VNevening talking about the honour of being VN Council Chair & all the positive developments in the profession including VN Futures & the new post-registration qualifications https://t.co/GQFIkNzxC5

Before she hands over to VN Council Chair Matthew Rendle for his address, she encourages those present to make a nomination for the VN Golden Jubilee Award ‚Äì the highest honour the RCVS bestows on vet nurses. More information here: https://t.co/A7rj4KdeKS #VNevening
Mandisa @rcvspresident particularly praises the newly-qualified RVNs who have achieved their qualifications under very unusual and challenging circumstances this year #VNevening

Questions from the audience cover the role of allies, how to achieve a diverse profession and what practical steps can be taken to reach it, and what the key barriers might be to BAME recruitment to vet school @rcvspresident #McCallLecture
.@RCVSpresident concludes her speech and says change requires adaptation and innovation and poses a question to the audience: how do you see the future of the profession? #McCallLecture

The final element of her vision for the profession is around acknowledging and recognising GP Vets - those doing the preventative medicine and day-to-day work might not get the headlines but the work is invaluable @RCVSpresident #McCallLecture

Her next vision is for a more diverse profession as it allows for more ideas, perspectives, ways of thinking and ways of doing in the profession which can only be for the benefit of animal welfare ultimately @RCVSpresident #McCallLecture

Her next vision is for a 'zero discrimination' profession where people's protected characteristics are respected - she hopes to see greater protections via the Code of Professional Conduct in addition to enforcement #McCallLecture

.@RCVSpresident says the key to being a vet is knowledge, communication and problem solving and the veterinary professions shouldn't exclude talented people on the basis of their disabilities - it will require change and innovation

The first is the need for greater accessibility to the professions for people with physical disabilities and she would like to see a day where this is not a barrier to a veterinary career #McCallLecture
She now sets out the four elements of her vision for how she wants to see the profession develop #McCallLecture

As the first Black President of the RCVS Mandisa acknowledges the historic and symbolic nature of her presidency and says that she wants to put her opportunity as a role model to good use to inspire others #McCallLecture #BlackHistoryMonth

A new opportunity was opened up for @RCVSpresident when she decided to start lecturing part time on the @HarperAdamsUni veterinary nursing course & then she ran for Junior VP as she felt she had the time, knowledge & energy needed

She says her career was somewhat upended by her mum developing cancer meaning she had additional caring responsibilities and so decided to locum - this development also led her to joining @VetlifeVBF as a volunteer #McCallLecture

Mandisa said she turned that fear and curiosity about the RCVS into action by deciding to run for #RCVSCouncil to gain more insight into the RCVS and how it regulates - and she, of course, successfully got on!

.@RCVSpresident talks about her interest in out-of-hour/ emergency work and how it fit well around her family life with two young children - but also says this is also when she   initially had some fear, as well as curiosity, about the RCVS

.@RCVSpresident also talks about her first veterinary job in Edinburgh with people who had mentored her while a student and how they were patient, let her learn from her mistakes and gain the experience she needed #McCallLecture

Mandisa @rcvspresident talks about a moving moment when she was welcomed into the profession by Professor Trees @Vet_Policy who told all the graduates to look at their loved ones & realise that the effort taken to graduate as a vet was theirs' as well #McCallLecture

Mandisa @RCVSpresident says her path to vet school was complicated - she was rejected upon her first applications and so undertook a BSc in Biological & Medicinal Chemistry and got in to @TheDickVet on the second time around #McCallLecture

.@RCVSpresident talks about her family background - she's the youngest of four children born in the space of 5 years, and while born in the UK she was raised in Trinidad and decided she wanted to be a vet from the age of 8 after caring for animals from an early age
.@RCVSpresident says that her lecture will set out her background and how it influences who she is today as well as setting out her vision for the veterinary profession's future #McCallLecture

Ewan Cameron @UofGlasgow introduces Mandisa @rcvspresident citing the fact that she is the first sitting RCVS President to do the lecture since 1976 as well as one of the youngest speakers #McCallLecture #BlackHistoryMonth

.@RCVSpresident will be starting her McCall Lecture ‚ÄòChanging the face of the Veterinary Profession: Adaptation and Innovation' @UofGlasgow in a few minutes - we will be tweeting some of the highlights from this account #BlackHistoryMonth

Thank you to @chernobylguy for a fascinating #InternationalDogDay talk about the great work he carries out and for showing us some of the dogs living in the exclusion zone #DogsofChernobyl - more information about the project can be found here: https://t.co/iQLqRyNgkz

Lucas @chernobylguy talks about long-term goal - they can't vaccinate and sterilise forever and so ultimately they want to found a sanctuary for the dogs within the exclusion zone to make sure they have food, veterinary care & safety from predation #DogsofChernobyl

The charity also proactively carries out veterinary work on #DogsofChernobyl - veterinarians can come on site for treatment or, for more complicated treatment and surgery, the dogs can be taken to Kiev which is around 2 hours away @chernobylguy

Lucas @chernobylguy says that after years of working with the dogs his team persuaded the Ukrainian govt that the dogs were not a threat to humans and started a rescue and adopt strategy - since then 50 puppies have been rescued and adopted #DogsofChernobyl

As shown in the Chernobyl TV series there was sadly mass-culling of dogs in the exclusion zone after the nuclear accident - but @chernobylguy  says the dogs are intelligent & adaptable and many learned how to avoid the culls - hence the large remaining population.

The dogs have quite a few challenges - the harsh Ukrainian winters (including the wind chill), disease and predation from wolves all limit life expectancy - radiation is not the main factor impacting them. The dogs tend to be quite large as a result #DogsofChernobyl
It's worth noting that this is a live interactive session - @chernobylguy is on site in the exclusion zone and interacting with some of the dogs as he speaks https://t.co/lx6VDwiNi1

The #dogsofchernobyl are now semi-feral, they are not completely domesticated but are not aggressive and have a good relationship with people - particularly if they get fed! Some are friendly, some are more wary though. @chernobylguy

Lucas @chernobylguy says that the dogs in the exclusion zone are descendants of the pets left behind when the area was abandoned in 1986. People were told they would only be gone for 3 days & to take what is strictly necessary and so left their animals behind

RCVS staff are very lucky to be holding a lunch and learn with environmental scientist Lucas Hixson @chernobylguy from @CleanFutureFund who works with abandoned and stray dogs in the Chernobyl exclusion zone #dogsofchernobyl

That concludes #RoyalCollegeDay2020 - videos of all the key speeches will shortly be published on the RCVS YouTube channels and special thanks go to Ian Holloway & Deb Rowlanes from the Coms Team and Paulette Brown & Richard Burley from the IT Team for making it all happen!

In conclusion, she says it's a great honour to be President and, while there is much to do, says we must continue to forge ahead, aspire to greatness and fulfil the strategic plan's goals of clarity, compassion, courage and confidence #RoyalCollegeDay2020

She said that she also is taking the baton from Niall to champion diversity & inclusion in the professions with renewed intensity, including the development of a concrete Action Plan through the RCVS Diversity & Inclusion Group #RoyalCollegeDay2020

In terms of her priorities as RCVS President, Mandisa picks out helping the College deliver the new Strategic Plan, recognising the contribution and value of General Practitioner vets and continuing to make EU colleagues in the UK feel welcomed #RoyalCollegeDay2020

She says she will use her presidential to be a role model for people from under-represented groups to consider veterinary medicine as a career and gives an example of where she encouraged a young Afro-Caribbean woman to successfully apply for vet school when she was unsure

Giving her opening address, Mandisa says that, 176 years ago when the College was founded, it would have been unthinkable that a woman, let alone a black woman, would be President and, while it shows progress, it is clear that more work needs to be done #RoyalCollegeDay2020

As Mandisa's first official job as RCVS President, she says she has the pleasure of welcoming Professor David Argyle on board the Officer Team as Junior Vice-President and Professor Susan Dawson as Treasurer #RoyalCollegeDay2020

On taking office as RCVS President, Mandisa praises Niall as not the 'Brexit' or the 'pandemic' President but as the 'cool, calm, collected President' who led the College during exceedingly difficult times #RoyalCollegeDay2020

We now move on to the investment of Dr Mandisa Greene as RCVS President with Niall 'passing on' his home-made Presidential Chain of Office to Mandisa, who, as the first black President of the College, he praises as a fantastic role-model #RoyalCollegeDay2020 https://t.co/k98BsPiBUz

For Amanda @RCVSpresident praises her intellect and good humour and, in particular, her year as President which saw her act as a skilled negotiator and spokesperson on behalf of the College throughout the Brexit process and negotiations #RoyalCollegeDay2020

For Kit @RCVSpresident praises his financial acumen and prudence as Treasurer and recognises his leading role in helping to mitigate some of the difficulties of the pandemic eg by allowing members to pay retention fees in instalments #RoyalCollegeDay2020 https://t.co/f2U9pnQXAI
Niall now moves on to thank Kit Sturgess and Amanda Boag who are retiring as Treasurer and Senior Vice-President respectively #RoyalCollegeDay2020

Niall gives particular thanks to the way in which the profession has risen up to the challenge of the pandemic, his colleagues on Council and the Officer Team, the RCVS staff and @RCVS_CEO Elizabeth Ann Lockett for her leadership during challenging times #RoyalCollegeDay2020

Now @RCVSpresident delivers an address regarding his somewhat unusual year but also picking out some key highlights including the extraordinary efforts of the RCVS to cope with the pandemic, the accreditation of Surrey vet school, the PSS marketing campaign and the work of MMI

She encourages veterinary nurses to 'think big and not be short-sighted' regarding the future of VNs. Following the end of her speech (available to view at https://t.co/USblxJkzbC) @RCVSpresident pays tribute to her diligence, hard-work & passion for advancing the profession

1/4 At its meeting yesterday, #RCVScouncil voted to consult on a set of recommendations from our Legislation Working Party (LWP) that could see wide-scale changes to the legislative framework governing the future regulation of the veterinary professions.
@ZotVet Hi Zoe. They will indeed be available for playback.

Speaking at the outset of yesterday‚Äôs online #RCVScouncil meeting, @RCVSpresident Niall Connell made the following statement in response to events surrounding the recent death of George Floyd in the USA. #BlackLivesMatter https://t.co/cgoR7WTWJh

Public session has now concluded with the date of the next #RCVSCouncil meeting confirmed as being Thursday 3 September - excluding the meeting of Council as part of the AGM proceedings on Friday 10 July

Now #RCVSCouncil moves on to reports from the Advancement of the Professions, Audit & Risk, DC/ PIC Liasion, Education, Finance & Resources and Standards Committees as well as VN Council. All papers available here: https://t.co/JkIeRreY75
2/2 This will be a separate consultation to the LWP Report as it does not require fresh legislation to enact but changes can be made under the ambit of the College's Royal Charter #RCVSCouncil
#RCVSCouncil agrees to take the disciplinary proposals on standard of proof, Charter Case Protocol and mini-PICs forward to consultation 1/2
Full details of all disciplinary proposals can be found in the Council papers: https://t.co/NikCLDDdT2

Eleanor also introduces #RCVSCouncil to the concept of 'mini-PICs' which could meet more frequently to make decisions on simpler cases and so speed up the conclusion of the concerns-investigation process for many cases

2/2 The Protocol allows cases which do not meet threshold for a full Disciplinary, but which are sufficiently serious to require intervention to safeguard animal health and welfare, to be consensually concluded by allowing the RCVS to publicly issue advice and/or warnings
She acknowledges the debates and concerns on potential change in standard of proof and says it needs to be considered as a package with the Charter Case Protocol #RCVSCouncil 1/2

Moving on RCVS Registrar Eleanor Ferguson introduces a paper on proposed changes to the disciplinary procedure, including potential changes to the standard of proof from the criminal to the civil standard #RCVSCouncil

In summing up @StephenMayVet thanks the Working Group members and staff and says: "this has been a journey, it's a radical set of proposals and will stimulate discussion, but it's an example of us all working together on a report that can helpfully stimulate debate."
#RCVSCouncil approves the Legislation Working Party Report to go to consultation later in the year with some debate around certain aspects of the recommendations such as limited licensure

Recommend reading the entire report to #RCVSCouncil & big kudos our Policy Manager Ben Myring for his authorship. 5 main themes: vet-led team; enhancing VN role; practice regulation; modern fitness to practise regime; and modernised registration processes: https://t.co/JkIeRreY75

#RCVSCouncil moves on to the Report of the Legislation Working Party from @StephenMayVet which sets out a series of recommendations for wide-reaching reform to the legislative basis for veterinary regulation to make it modern, clear, flexible & encompassing entire vet-team

The next item on the #RCVSCouncil agenda is some changes to the Delegation Scheme which determines the composition, terms of reference and decision-making powers for various RCVS Committees. Full details in the papers: https://t.co/JkIeRreY75

The agenda now moves on to changes to the Practice Standards Scheme which #RCVSCouncil votes to approve. The changes will come into affect later this year and a news story/ release will be published on this in due course

Following the under care review update, Council then approved a decision to add an addendum to the MRA with @of_veterinary to tie up a loophole around those who had previously failed the Stat Exam being able to register in the UK. Full details here: https://t.co/Dn4RZUuGIz

2/2 @RCVS_CEO added that, where appropriate, some discussions will continue to be held in confidence, but that the rationale behind this will be given for each item in the agenda held in committee #RCVSCouncil

2/2 New methods will involve focus group discussions to gather evidence, followed by a detailed online consultation/ survey with the whole profession. She said that, regrettably, this has led to a delay in timetable but consultation will launch towards end of year #RCVSCouncil

#RCVSCouncil approves the 2020 - 2024 RCVS Strategic Plan which will be published in due course. The plan has been in development since the end of 2018 and many Council members praised the hard-work that went into it @RCVS_CEO
.@RCVS_CEO now introduces the RCVS Strategic Plan for 2020 to 2024 for consideration by #RCVSCouncil - the draft plan revolves around '4 Cs': clarity, compassion, courage & conviction

#RCVSCouncil approves a new re-sit policy for the Statutory Examination for Membership (for overseas vets with unrecognised degrees who wish to work in the UK) - full details here: https://t.co/zkT6tM6kYL

#RCVSCouncil approves the final element of the Graduate Outcomes proposals which will see the Working Party carrying out further work on proposals for EMS and general practice education. The consensus from the consultation was less clear for these & further work needed

#RCVSCouncil agrees the proposals put forward by @StephenMayVet  for the overhaul of the PDP. This now moves to the development phase which is expected to last around one year, with a new programme expected to be introduced within 2 years

Now @StephenMayVet is talking about the proposed overhaul of the Professional Development Phase to move it away from what he calls a 'tick-box exercise' & strengthen its mentoring and support elements to help graduates transition into practice life #RCVSCouncil

.#RCVSCouncil first approves a new conceptual model for the Day One Competences - the professional skills and knowledge expected of new graduates - to make it clearer what's required of them and how it applies to clinical practice

@StephenMayVet chaired the Graduate Outcomes Working Group & introduces the paper on the proposals stemming from the project. This consulted the profession on 4 issues: Day One Competences, the Professional Development Phase, EMS & clinical education for general practice

#RCVSCouncil approves an addendum to the Practice Standards Scheme rules around data sharing and an update to the Certificate in Advanced Veterinary Practice and moves on to a discussion about the Graduate Outcomes project

@Melissavet64 introduces the first item at #RCVSCouncil regarding the under care/ out-of-hours review saying that the planning of the review is taking longer than anticipated, but that it is important to get it right. There will be further updates in due course.

@RCVS_CEO now gives her #RCVSCouncil update on what has happened over last few months including VN renewals, the PSS social media campaign, the VN Futures and @vetmindmatters webinars, the Trust Index survey and CPD policy changes. Details of all here: https://t.co/4QgUJN7Oyx

.@RCVSpresident brings our proceedings in #Nottingham to a close, thanking everyone for all their questions and input into this evening's discussions. Our next regional question time will be in spring 2020, location tbc #RCVSrqt
Meanwhile, v important to get practice support from colleagues, legal support from prof indemnity insurers and emotional support from friends and family. 4/4 #RCVSrqt

Some cases can take longer than normal to progress, for a variety of reasons on either side. We‚Äôre very mindful of stress that concerns investigation has for both parties, and we‚Äôre always looking for best ways to progress cases as quickly and carefully as possible. 3/4 #RCVSrqt

...compassion, fairness and as quickly as possible for benefit of all involved. In order to be able to bring complaints to a proper conclusion, there needs to be enough information gathered to make a decision one way or another - can take a long time. 2/4 #RCVSrqt

Q. How can complaints raised with the College be expedited to reduce stress on people in practice?
A. Important to recognise there are always two sides to same story, which College has duty to gather. RCVS is there for public interest, but aims to work with... 1/4 #RCVSrqt

...importance of general practice, including how #EBVM can support decision-making in practice; how PSS can help support models best practice; and how Leadership initiative can help boost career development and fulfilment in all spheres of veterinary work 2/2 #RCVSrqt

Q. Concern voiced about decreasing value seemingly placed on working in first-opinion practice.
A. Key element of #GradOutcomes consultation is considering clinical education in general practice. We‚Äôre also working on other ways in which to promote & support vital... 1/2 #RCVSrqt

@vetmindmatters Also working with others to look at career diversity within the professions, & helping people to remain fulfilled within their career, whilst also exploring other options. Impact of societal change also discussed, where people might not want a ‚Äòjob for life‚Äô any more 3/3 #RCVSrqt

A. No one particular driver causing people to leave. Our @vetmindmatters initiative is looking at mental health and resilience within the professions, raising awareness of issues and giving people the tools and knowledge to help themselves and others #RCVSrqt 2/3

Q Does RCVS collect & analyse breakdown of people leaving the profession?
A Difficulty is a lot of people leaving profession just stop paying fees & so come off Register. GDPR then makes it difficult to contact them, but we do get some feedback in surveys we supply #RCVSrqt 1/3
Useful overview of #UnderCare review plans published by @Vet_Record last week: https://t.co/mZrx862527 #RCVSrqt

RCVS Registrar Eleanor Ferguson gives a brief background & overview to the upcoming #UnderCare review. Reassurance that call for evidence will ask v open questions, & emphasis that we need to hear from as many people in as many spheres as poss, including the public #RCVSrqt
2/2 ...we're working on ways to demonstrate this value to employers and clients alike #RCVSrqt

Q What can College do to help RVNs struggling with low salaries and feeling undervalued.
A Whilst College can‚Äôt have any direct influence over salaries (more BVNA‚Äôs remit) we recognise the huge value RVNs play in practice and, as part of VN Futures project... 1/2 #RCVSrqt

And time's up for the last @BritishVets hot topic for today. Anyone who couldn't make today's conversation should check out @Melissavet64's column in tomorrow's @Vet_Record which gives an overview of the background to and plans for our #UnderCare review #vetshow

Q Will delay to start of call for evidence mean that the later deadlines will also be moved back? @Melissavet64 We‚Äôre hoping to conclude #UnderCare review around the published deadlines, but this topic is too important to rush, so more time may be allocated if necessary. #vetshow

Q. How will responses to call for evidence be synthesised? 
@Melissavet64 The independent research agency will be responsible for this, including recommending the most appropriate methodology and analysis to use. #UnderCare #vetshow @BritishVets

Q. Is there an argument for greater clarity in the guidance? @Melissavet64: The more prescriptive you make the guidance, the less professional judgement would play a part. Very important to strike the right balance, but it‚Äôs very difficult. #UnderCare #vetshow @BritishVets

Q. Are we trying to solve a problem, or create a better future? @Melissavet64: Really hope it‚Äôs both! There are some anomalies to resolve, but what an opportunity to improve things for future generations! #vetshow @BritishVets

Q. Shouldn't under care be left as a professional decision? @Melissavet64: Professional decisions are v much at core of this discussion, but anomalies exist across different sectors, so we need to provide more guidance to help iron these out #vetshow @BritishVets

.@VetDannii does College have view on whether a one-size-fits-all approach will work? @Melissavet64 says that this approach won't work - what works in one area may not be applicable in another. Another reason we need to hear from as many people as possible. #vetshow @BritishVets

.@Melissavet64: Aim of #UnderCare review is to go back to first principles, to see what 'under care' means to people in different spheres and different areas of work. The review will also invite responses from members of the public. #vetshow @BritishVets

After an intro from @VetDannii, the @BritishVets conversation session on our #UnderCare review gets underway, with an overview from our Standards Committee chair @Melissavet64 #vetshow https://t.co/wlsHSoFFAj

She says that other issues include lack of role models, the lack of visibility in career opportunities, lack of knowledge on cultural significance of animals, STEM discipline challenges, the role of class privilege & educational disadvantages #RoyalCollegeDay19

In terms of tackling diversity issues Patricia highlights the establishment of the National Association of Black Veterinarians which held its inaugural conference in 2019 which has been a positive move and also says that key aspect in tackling is to admit there‚Äôs a problem

Talking from the US point of view she says that the increasing diversity of society in the US is not reflected in the number of vet students from black and minority ethnic backgrounds #RoyalCollegeDay19

She speaks about her journey from a council estate in North London to receiving her DVM from Cambridge University, but says that it took close to 10 years in the UK veterinary world until she found another black person working in the profession #RoyalCollegeDay19
Patricia is an ophthalmologist at the Matthew J Ryan Veterinary Hospital at the University of Pennsylvania who is also lead veterinary ophthalmologist for the NYPD #RoyalCollegeDay19

Changes include: changing CPD requirement to 35 hours per year for vets & 15 hours for VNs; making new CPD recording system mandatory from 2022; encourage vets/VNs to download CPD compliance certificate; & introduce admin fee for serial non-compliance or responding vets/VNs

Final item for #RCVSCouncil decision is changes to CPD policy - particularly around the issues of continuous non-compliance, failure to respond to CPD requests from the College and no need to confirm compliance before confirming registration

The @ViVetUK innovation workshop has come to a close and, from these results, it looks like the delegates thoroughly enjoyed it and found it very insightful! Thank you to all who came! https://t.co/U2puP6yyMk

He says that sometimes you also need to be prepared to walk away from a project if it just isn't working, can't be brought into fruition or would bring reputational damage. Failure is a fact of business and the key is to deal with it honestly and ethically @ViVetUK
He says that if the public hasn't 'got' your story, then it is your fault and you need to look again and question your message, how you are getting it out and who is delivering it @ViVetUK
Guest speaker Tim Bowdin now gives a presentation on how to convince people to support your innovative idea talking about his experiences of working in the drinks industry @ViVetUK

@ViVetUK Anthony Roberts says that good business models are like good stories explaining how your product works - telling who the customer is and what they value, how the business makes money and how value is delivered at an appropriate cost.
Anthony Roberts says that, while innovation is often equated with tech and tech alone, business model innovation sometimes has a bigger impact on the market eg Monzo banking, Uber etc. @ViVetUK
Those key resources for consideration in a business model could include capital, branches, financial expertise & security, the brand itself and any relevant quality/kitemarks @ViVetUK

The discussion now moves on to the resources/ supply-side of a successful business model which should consider if resources are: valuable, rare, inimitable and if the business is sufficiently structured to exploit those resources at your disposal @ViVetUK

Anthony now considers what type of relationship innovative businesses have with each customer segment eg is it personal or automated, what are the motivations that drive the relationship (acquisition? retention? sales?) and how can customers be kept @ViVetUK

Innovators need to think about their customer focus eg whether they focus on a mass market, a niche market, a 'segmented' market (offering different services to different segments), a diversified customer base or a 'multi-sided' one eg appealing to 2 distinct markets @ViVetUK
@ViVetUK - value can be created through cost, price and risk reduction, accessibility, convenience, design, brand, performance and 'newness'
Anthony Roberts says that a good business model always starts with a value proposition setting out how your product solves a problem and how it benefits and creates value for the customer @ViVetUK

Anthony highlights difference between business plan & business model - a business plan rarely survives first contact with the customer & so should be greater focus on business models - flexible frameworks for how an organisation operates @ViVetUK
Soon we will be moving on to the day's second session - a talk on developing and refining business models from Anthony Roberts, RCVS Director of Leadership & Innovation @ViVetUK

Thank you to @GregJEDickens and Guen Bradbury for an interesting and thought-provoking discussion about the nature of innovation and how individuals and businesses can take a concept to market @ViVetUK
@GregJEDickens and Guen's presentation is available to download in PDF format from https://t.co/zAAGjB2YB4 and will also be published on the resources section of @ViVet website in due course.

The best hybrid models use the Scientific Method of observe, hypothesise, test and modify and the 'design thinking' model for product development = empathise (with stakeholder), define (the need), develop a concept, develop a prototype and then test it in market @ViVetUK
Both 'stage gate' and 'lean start-up' models have disadvantages & so companies often develop hybrid models for products eg launch a product then carry out stage gate analysis @ViVetUK

@GregJEDickens says that all you need for a lean start-up is an 'MVP' or minimum viable product - it doesn't need to be perfect, turn a profit or be 'easy, pretty or efficient' but it is crucial for learning & development @ViVetUK
Other end of the spectrum is 'lean start-up' in which you put your product out there, learn on the go and build, measure & learn from failure & mistakes @GregJEDickens @ViVetUK

@GregJEDickens talks about 'stage gate innovation' in which companies reduce risk of product failure by asking and resolving five key questions before product launch. Tends to be used in high-risk industries but is mostly inappropriate for start-ups & small business @ViVetUK

@GregJEDickens says that in developing a concept, innovators first have to determine if it is practical, useful and meets a particular need and, if it is, then take the concept out to stakeholders for feedback @ViVetUK

Speakers today include veterinary innovators Greg Dickens and Guen Bradbury from @Innovia_Tech who talk about how to approach the development of your concept for veterinary & animal health innovation @ViVetUK

Today is the second @ViVetUK innovation workshop, building upon January's event and looking at how you can take forward ideas, develop business plans and build a narrative for investors and backers. Follow @ViVetUK for live tweets from the event. https://t.co/sxGmNOt9RJ

@Melissavet64 Hi Melissa.  Correct, post-mortem exam implies that a diagnosis is being made and opinion provided regarding disease or injury. Diagnosis is something that only a vet can undertake & so it would not be appropriate under the VSA for a non-vet to undertake a post-mortem exam.

During the trial period the Ethics Review Panel reviewed 58 applications from researchers who may not have been able to obtain the approval and guidance elsewhere. Kate also reports that the feedback has been positive & current arrangements working well #RCVSCouncil

Kate Richards, Chair of Standards Cttee, now introduces a paper to make the Ethics Review Panel - which has been trialled for the past 2 years - a permanent fixture, providing ethical review for researchers who may not have access to traditional academic routes #RCVSCouncil

#RCVSCouncil agreed the paper in principle but also decided to bring the details of procedures for voting - including recorded votes - back to the next meeting of Council in March for further discussion
Discussion moves on to amendments to meeting procedure rules - including the ability for members of #RCVSCouncil to make use of an electronic voting system
Council approves recommended changes to the College's delegation scheme including terms of reference for the new Advancement of the Professions Committee and the College's Senior Team #RCVSCouncil

@RCVS_CEO now gives her update - including the fact that the #GradOutcomes consultation (ends tomorrow!) has 1,780 full responses and 3,750 partial responses. If you've partially completed it or haven't started it yet - please do let us know your views.
